abstracts.cdata!:
The second tranche of the Second
            Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL) Project for Yugoslavia was
            not released and the loan closed on September 30, 1991, six
            months after the original closing date. At that time the
            remaining balance was canceled. The government was unable to
            ensure that the National Bank of Yugoslavia (NBY) would act
            as an autonomous institution in full control of monetary
            policy. The lessons learned from this project contained a
            comprehensive list of structural measures and was intended
            to be implemented along with a strong IMF stabilization
            program. Though the complete dissolution of the country
            could not have been predicted, perhaps the riskiness of the
            loan was underestimated.
